subject: add clang-tidy
commitMessage:
add clang-tidy

This commit implements a clang-tidy file, and makes some changes to get
it to pass.  Most changes are naming or mechanical in nature.

Tested:
Clang-tidy now passes.

Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <ed@tanous.net>
Change-Id: Ia441e4801b6c8725421d160c531c5df141f255d4

Patch Set 39:

I'm merging this.  This is finding more and more issues with every commit, and it's at the point where it will help a lot more than it will harm.
Change has been successfully merged by Ed Tanous
Damn, this was supposed to get filtered.  Will fix.
why is the default parameter changed split into two separate functions?
Because it removed the warning, and makes it explicit which method you're going to.
Ack
I believe this is a kernel driver header file. May want to keep the kernel naming convention.

I already commented this earlier.  Still working on fixing it, although the PECI discussion on the mailing list needs to complete.  This file really shouldn't be here at all, but the PECI stuff isn't in the mainline kernel yet.
Sorry, I did not look at existing comments and missed it. It is best that if this header does not need to be in here.
Why rand() was removed?

https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clang-tidy/checks/cert-msc51-cpp.html

rand was never seeded properly.  In this case, it's not really needed.  If we want to add dithering to sensor scans, we need to be consistent, and do it for all sensors.

With that said, this line is wrong, and completely ignored the sensorPollMs variable.

Even though it is not truly randomized, the poll time does vary between each read. I am just a little concerned about making it a fixed number. Having said that, I can't think of anything concrete now.

> Even though it is not truly randomized, the poll time does vary between each read. I am just a little concerned about making it a fixed number. Having said that, I can't think of anything concrete now.

the poll time will vary anyway with normal system load.  Having a non-integer scan rate makes things much harder for the PID tuning loops.  If we're going to do that, we should do it everywhere, not in this one specific sensor.
That is a good point
uint32_t here?

That would result in signed vs unsigned problems on line 130.  I'd much rather do the conversion here, where we're dealing with constants that we know don't overflow.

This code could also be cleaned up a lot to not rely on masks for this kind of stuff, but this is better than what we have.
That is fair, bit masks, manipulation should not be mixed with signed function returns.
uint32_t here?
Technically this should be uint8_t, but that would lead to worse overflows.
Ack
toupper?
Will fix.

just FYI I don't think gcc needs it either:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openpower-proc-control/+/37836
Neat.  I was unaware they dropped that restriction.  Will fix.
Unintended whitespace?
Looks like..... it's strange clang-format didn't catch that.  Will fix.
Nit: Is the intention here to be 10 times of normal poll period? or should sensorFailedPollTimeMs or fixed 10 seconds be used?
This is meant to be 10X the current poll time, used for when the sensor fails, such that it doesn't poll as often.
This is a good idea, instead of depending on rand(). However, I agree that it should be a constant, like sensorFailedPollTimeMs. Multiplying by 10 is somewhat of an arbitrary magic number here.

It's less arbitrary than rand()  😊

This could be a constant, but that would take this significantly beyond the scope of this patchset, which is adding clang-tidy support and resolving the tidy issues.

I'll add it as a possible improvement in the future, but in the context of this patchset, I think this is the way to go.
Ack
This looks like a behavior change. Should this be toupper()?
good catch.  will fix.
Does this file come from anywhere, or is it all original content? If it comes from somewhere, then where?
Depends on how you define original.  I wrote it originally for bmcweb.

Sounds good. Are comments allowed in this file, to mention that? Also, will this file proliferate into many multiple copies everywhere? I am guessing this is like a .clang-format file, in that you need to copy it everywhere it's needed, unfortunately, because clang-format does a directory-specific search when ran, so you can't just reference a common copy of it held elsewhere.

I don't believe comments are allowed.  There's a patchset to add this to the docs repo so we don't proliferate, although each individual repo will have its own styles to some extent, given where they are today.
I wonder why it wanted "path" to be reconstructed like that here?
I suspect because path is a reference, using path would always be a copy, whereas this in theory could use RVO to make it a move?  Just a guess in the blind.

Might also be because the lambda is capturing by copy, and so it wants to construct it again so it can copy the reference object.

It does seem like a micro-optimization to want to have "path" be a reference and not just an ordinary variable that can be passed around when needed.

But it's not a reference here.  It's taken by value/new construction, so the old code and this should be equivalent as far as the compiler is concerned......   It's too early for this kind of thinking.
I believe this is a workaround for a bug in C++17 not supporting structured binding. GCC allows it, but clang does not. This is fixed in C++20
OK, makes sense. Might want to put a comment here explaining this, for the next reader who wonders why this was done.

I can't fully explain why it was done, so I'm worried about adding a comment that's incorrect.  I would much rather it just "look weird" for now, so hopefully someone with more knowledge can see it and fix it at some point.
Interesting, did not know about std::from_chars(), curious why this change? It's not a purely mechanical change like the others.

std::from_chars is just better in nearly every way, unless you care about locale stuff.

1. It returns an error code instead of throwing.
2. It can handle any int type through the template that supports std::numeric_limits (ie all of them), not just the few that are defined for stoul
3. It has better defined behavior when you're reading into an integer type that might need to be downcast to a smaller type (ie, it doesn't need the down cast at all).
4. It doesn't pull in locale code, and isn't locale specific.


It was done here because we were getting a warning on compressing an unsigned long into an int, whereas with from_chars, we can load data into the int directly.  I would've called this a mechanical change, but I'm happy to mention it in the commit message if you want.
Nice, that makes sense. It would be worth mentioning some of these advantages, perhaps in a comment, as to why an ordinary std::stoul() wasn't done anymore.

I'm going to answer no in this case;  from_chars is used often enough across the project that requiring a comment for every invocation would be a lot of extra code.  We've already gone through replacing them in other repos, and haven't added the "why this is better" comment.

Coming up to 1000ft view, if we had to add an inline comment for every language feature we swapped in that was better (std::variant, std::span, std::optional, std::array, ect) half the code would be comments about that.
This looks like a downgrade in the syntax of this for-loop, curious why that had to be?

in theory it's an upgrade, because we're now using the built-in methods for walking symlinks rather than trying to recurse them ourselves.

This was found because clang-tidy (rightly) warns on recursion, as in some extreme cases it can pop the stack.  Probably unlikely in this case, but worth it to change to get the check enabled.
Makes sense, but couldn't you have just added fs::directory_options::follow_directory_symlink to the parameters, without changing the syntax of the for-loop?
This is a functional change, not just a syntax cleanup, but it's a good bug fix. Apply the depth limitation to all subdirectories/symlinks, instead of just applying it to only symlinks.

In theory the behavior is identical, in the old patchset we decremented symlinkDepth before recursing, so it should've worked properly, this is just a change to support changing to relying on the recursive symlink iterator instead.

The old recursion call would act only if it encountered a symlink. The new code doesn't have an is_symlink() test here, so it would appear to act on all directories encountered, not just symlinks. This is the change I noticed.

in the old code, the recursive_directory_iterator was handling recursion for normal files, and the is_symlink case was handling recursion for symlinks.  In the new code, recursive_directory_iterator handles for both, but you make a good point that now depth applies to not just symlinks, but for all things.

The depth thing was really only there to stop circular symlinks (like exist in hwmon) from recursing forever, for which I think this still works.  With that said, I can try to see if I can get the old behavior.
